content: quote: The United States is jeopardizing its chances of success in Afghanistan by mistakenly inflicting casualties on civilians in airstrikes that undermine support for the war among the general population, the top U.S. military officer said. Adm. Michael G. Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, cited the aerial bombing this month of a village in western Afghanistan that killed an undetermined number of civilians as one that occurred despite changes in procedures aimed at reducing such deaths. “We cannot succeed in Afghanistan, or anywhere else — but let’s talk specifically about Afghanistan — by killing Afghan civilians,” Mullen told experts and scholars at the Brookings Institution in Washington. “We can’t keep going through incidents like this and expect the strategy to work.” (Los Angeles Times, May 19, 2009, Pg. 18) I would think ADM was stating the obvious...were others confused?! "None are more hopelessly enslaved than those who falsely believe they are free." -Johann Wolfgang von Goethe

content: The Admiral is thinking 'strategy', so he can't get his mind around the 'tragedy' involved in every single civilian death. How many times has he denied incidents only to later admit they're true but still quibble? And he claims to 'know' what he's talking about? Dropping bombs, and being there when they land are two polar and incomparable experiences. The potential 'success' of these atrocities being forgiven or forgotten by Afghans is about as good as Bin Laden getting a Presidential Medal of Freedom.
